heading: asteroid, inbound, 2044 ad
subheading: an astronomer working out of his backyard helps researchers track an asteroid that is hurtling toward a planet near you. by lindsey arent.
author: lindsey arent
text: an amateur astronomer's backyard observations have helped researchers calculate that an asteroid is headed this way, and could pass earth even closer than the moon. "1999 an10 is about half a mile in size and the probability is 1 in 500,000 that it will collide with the earth in 2044," said dr. brian marsden, director of the minor planet center (mpc), a clearinghouse for data about asteroids and comets traveling through the solar system."it's not a threat in 2027, but it might be threat in 2044. it's possible, but very unlikely, that it could hit the earth then," said marsden. "it's not a high probability, but one shouldn't ignore a probability."last month, marsden contacted amateur sky-watcher frank zoltowski when researchers lost track of the asteroid 1999 an10 in the skies of the northern hemisphere.zoltowski, who since 1997 had been tracking celestial objects with equipment that he had cobbled together, had a better chance of locating the object. that's because he was conducting his observations from a small village in the australian outback, located in the southern hemisphere.zoltowski located the missing asteroid from a small observing station he built in his backyard. he rigged his telescope to a charge-coupled device (ccd) camera that he received as part of a gene shoemaker near-earth object grant from the planetary society, an organization dedicated to the exploration and observation of neos.with a guiding scope hooked on top of the main instrument, he was able to track the asteroid's position by the stars. using a smaller ccd camera connected to the guiding telescope, and a software program he modified to keep the telescope positioned properly, zoltowski was able to locate and record images of the asteroid."the threat about these kinds of asteroids is they could potentially hit the earth," said zoltowski. "it's rewarding as an amateur astronomer to contribute to the astronomy community. the asteroid won't get lost and its orbit will be known well enough so that people can keep track of its movement in the sky.""you want to catalog the asteroids that are a threat to the earth," he continued. "if you catch them early enough, you might be able to deflect them or shift their orbit a bit."
